abstract.text: Create an account sign-up and sign-in strategy for your app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Users can launch an independent watchOS app as soon as it downloads, even if they
don’t have their iPhone. As a result, users must be able to set up the application
directly on Apple Watch. If your app requires an account, users must be able to create
it and sign in on the watch.
You have the following options for syncing or saving user data:
Create an app that doesn’t require user accounts. Design your app so that it provides
a full set of features without user accounts, or use CloudKit to sync and store your
user’s data. Apps can access CloudKit data based on the user’s Apple ID without in-app
sign-in. watchOS 6 and later also supports CloudKit subscriptions and notifications
to let your app respond to changes from other devices.
Authenticate users with Sign In with Apple. This feature authenticates users based
on their Apple ID. For more information, see
and
Create custom sign-in and sign-up forms.
If you choose to create custom forms, watchOS 6 provides tools designed to fit the
small screen size and to streamline data entry on Apple Watch.
Create your sign-in and sign-up forms using text fields. In SwiftUI, use the
and
structures.
In the storyboard, use the
class.
To streamline data entry, perform the following steps:
Set the text field’s content type. The text field’s content type modifies how
the text input controller and Apple Continuity Keyboard behave. For SwiftUI, set
the content type by calling the text field’s
method. For the storyboard, set the content type using the Attributes inspector.
Provide a placeholder that describes the text field’s expected content. Effective
placeholders help you get the most out of Apple Watch’s smaller screen. For SwiftUI,
when instantiating the text field, the
property sets the placeholder. For
the storyboard, set the placeholder using the Attributes inspector. Note that the
system truncates placeholders if the text is too long, so keep your placeholders
short.
Set up your app’s associated domains. If you have a website where users can sign
in with the same username and password, associate the website’s domain with your
app. An associated domain tells the Apple Continuity Keyboard to provide autofill
suggestions for usernames and passwords from that domain. To learn how to set up
your app’s associated domains, see
To support password autofill on Apple Watch, set the following
values.
Credential
Content Type
User Name
Password
New Password

Content Type attribute in the Attributes inspector.
watchOS provides an autofill suggestion for
fields after receiving an SMS message that contains a one-time code.
If you place a
or
text field on the same screen as a
text field,
the Apple Continuity Keyboard attempts to fill both fields. Similarly, if you put
two
fields on the same screen, the keyboard
automatically fills both when the user selects the suggested password.
For more information, see

abstract.text: Use App Intents to register actions for your app.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Responding to the Action button on Apple Watch Ultra

abstract.text: Make it easy for users to log into apps and services.
Streamline your app’s login and onboarding procedures.
A control into which people securely enter private text.
A control that displays an editable text interface.
Sets the text content type for this view, which the system uses to offer suggestions while the user enters text on a watchOS device.
A button that you can use to trigger a Sign in with Apple request.
An interface element that displays an editable text area.
Constants that specify a text field’s semantic meaning.
An email address.
A new password.
A one-time code.
An existing password.
An account or login name.
Connect your app and a website to provide both a native app and a browser experience.
Build watchOS apps that combine complications, notifications, and Siri to create
a personal experience on Apple Watch.
Set up a watchOS app that installs and runs without a companion iOS app.
Customize your app’s response to the double-tap gesture on Apple Watch.

doc://com.apple.watchOS-Apps/documentati.title: Enabling the double-tap gesture on Apple Watch

abstract.text: Ensure that your app’s content is relevant and up to date.

abstract.text: Create a new watchOS project or add a watch target to an existing iOS project.
Seamlessly schedule updates to your user interface, even while it’s inactive.
